title: jewish cousins reunited seperated romania holocaust ww2
story: Morris Sana, now , and Simon Mairowitz, now , were filmed sharing a tearful hug in Tel Aviv, Israel, after spending  years apart. Sana, who lives in Israel, can be seen walking into a hotel room before bursting into a beaming smile when he sees Mairowitz, who lives in the UK, standing and waiting for him. As the men embrace each other and begin to cry, Mairowitz says: “Good to see you after all these years. Seventy-five years you waited.”“You can see me now, cant you ”Weeping, Sana replies: “Good to see you.”The last time the two men saw each other was when they were living in Romania where they grew up as close friends.That was until a fascist uprising saw the government deposed and their country become a puppet state of the Nazis.Both managed to flee with their separate families, meaning neither had any idea the other had survived the holocaust, People reports.Sana eventually settled in Ra’anana, Israel, while Mairowitz lived in the UK.They were finally reunited when Sanas daughter began connecting with her long-lost cousins on Facebook and then realised Mairowitz was alive. That led Mairowitz to fly from Britain to Tel Aviv last week where he reunited with Sana in an emotional moment which was caught on camera. At the start of the footage, Sana can be seen walking into a hotel room filled with smiling relatives where Mairowitz is waiting for him.As he turns the corner he cracks a smile and holds his arms in the air as he recognises his old pal.

title: amazon brexit violent language
story: It comes the same week MPs urged Boris Johnson to temper his political language.The blank notebook was described as a book and journal for Remainers and EU voters and was listed for £..It has a blue cover and the title is surrounded by yellow stars - similar to the flag of the European Union.The notebook comes amid uproar over the Prime Ministers use of the term Surrender Bill in how he described a new law which will force the PM to get another extension from the EUhe doesnt get a deal.The official Leave.EU twitter account said: Remainers are crying crocodile tears over Boriss language, yet Amazon is stocking and selling a notebook called My Little Book Of All The Brexiteers I Want To Stab.Does anyone from @AmazonUK care to explain why they think this is in any way acceptable One person replied: Who published this ... Remainers is this what youre about Share this, we must have our remainer MPs explaining their vile incitement to violence.Another added: Amazon is selling a book inciting violence against the democratic majority who won the referendum  voted Leave.Is this ok behaviour in a democracy from the Remainer Establishment Remainer Publishing, the listed seller for the toxic product, wrote: Get this journal notebook and put a smile on the face of anyone who is against Brexit, who voted Britain to stay, who dont want Britain to leave the European Union!This is a great notebook journal for all anti-Brexit Remainers and Pro-Europeans, Anti Leave British supporters who want Britain to remain in the European Union.Customers on Amazon were disgusted over the notebook as one wrote in the review section: I hope this has been reported to the police for inciting hate.Another added: Would give zero starsI could. I am reporting this.Amazon has not commented on the listing, but has since taken it down.The PM was attacked on Wednesday by MPs for suggesting that the best way to honour the memory of murdered MP Jo Cox was to get Brexit done.He infuriated MPs by brushing off their concerns about his use of language in the Commons as humbug in more astonishing scenes.Paula Sherf told him many Labour MPs were being subjected to death threats from people quoting his words such as “Surrender Act”, “traitor” or “betrayal”.The PM dismissed her comments as “humbug” and on Wednesday refused to answer demands for an apology in the Commons — sending a junior minister instead.Brendan Cox — Jo’s widower — said he felt “sick” to see her name used by the PM. And former ­Labour leader Ed Miliband said it was a “disgrace” Mr Johnson did not apologise.Yesterday, Mr Johnson admitted that tempers need to come down in the furious row over political language and Jo Cox.He said he would carry on using the phrase to describe a new law - but stressed that MPs must be careful about what language they use to avoid inciting violence.The Sun Online contacted Downing Street for a comment.

title: baby 16 weeks premature 1st birthday
story: Haris was born  weeks premature, weighing just lb oz and given little chance of survival by doctors.His lungs were under-developed and diseased, leaving him unable to breathe on his own.After he clung to le for two weeks, his parents, Ellie Barr, , and Hassan Mockbill, , were told to say their goodbyes.Doctors tried one last-ditch treatment, a course of steroids, and, against all odds, it worked. Weeks later, Haris was well enough to leave intensive care.A year on, he weighs a stone, is taking his first steps and growing into the playful, cheeky boy his parents hoped for.Community worker Ellie said: “He overcame everything that was thrown at him. He never gave up.“We are a perfect little family now and it was so worth all of the fighting.”Ellie, from Birmingham, experienced frequent heavy bleeding throughout her pregnancy and was closely monitored by doctors at the city’s Heartlands Hospital.But, on July  last year, after one heavy bout of bleeding, Haris was born at  weeks — days after the legal limit for an abortion.Ellie, who has a two-year-old son, Elias, said: “He just decided he was coming. I had to push.“We had no ideahe was alive or not. I couldn’t hold him until he was ten days old. It was horrible.“We had no ideahe would make it or not.”Doctors smothered him in bubble wrap to stabilise his temperature. But Haris’s lungs were not strong enough to work alone and he was dependent on a ventilator.At two weeks, his health faded as his lungs filled with fluid.Ellie and Hassan, a roadside assistant, were taken into a room and told their son probably would not make it through the day.Ellie said: “He was really struggling to breathe and his body was shutting down.“I tried to cling on to any bit of hope but the doctors said it would probably be our last day with him.”Doctors injected him with steroids to clear the fluid from his lungs.The eight-day course saved his le and Ellie said: “When he pulled through we just couldn’t believe it. He has never stopped fighting.”At  weeks, his condition had improved and Haris was transferred to a special care ward.To celebrate this major breakthrough, the family held a special graduation ceremony. Because Haris was so small, his parents ordered his gown from a teddy bear factory.He was discharged  days later on October . But he was still very poorly and would require round-the-clock care from his parents.By March, Haris was able to breathe unaided and, in July, his parents celebrated his first birthday with another big party.He faces more health battles. A bleed on the brain threatens to leave a disability — another setback for Ellie and Hassan, who has a third son, Kaysan, nine.“It was hard to take but as long as he’s still with us and not in pain, that’s all that matters,” said Ellie. “He is a true inspiration and I am so proud of him.”The family spoke out to promote World Prematurity Day on November . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: armed forces short of bullets pilots
story: New Defence Minister Ben Wallace also revealed the MoD considered pulling out of some Nato commitments too.The dangerous overstretch is only ending after Mr Wallace persuaded Boris Johnson to intervene with a £.bn cash injection during the Whitehall-wide spending review three weeks ago.The Cabinet’s new defence supremo lted the lid on the true state of the nation’s defences in his first interview in the job with The Sun.Ahead of the start of the Tories’ annual conference in Manchester tomorrow, ex-Scot Guards officer Mr Wallace told The Sun: “I came to a department where I found for decades that we had pushed off budget decisions, while all the time growing our ambitions.“That had been done by successive governments, where Prime Ministers and some of our military leaders have had bigger appetites than their stomachs.“That has led to a consistent hollowing out of things that are incredibly vital to the day to day workings of the armed forces – such as maintenance, stocks, buildings, refurbishment of vehicles… everything.”He explained: “That ultimately leads you to a place whereyou stop the music, the whole thing was at risk of us being unable to meet our NATO obligations and to give the right protection in the right place to our country.”“In practical terms, that would have meant less readiness and less ability to protect our interests, in places like the Straits of Hormuz. Our ships were exhausted.”Mr Wallace also revealed he discovered a pilot training programme with a backlog of  trainees, meaning “we don’t have enough pilots to fly all our planes we’ve been buying”.He added: “This money will help us fix the problems in that pilot training.”Most alarming of all, Mr Wallace said he also discovered how low the Army’s ammunition stocks had got, as his successors saved cash by not replenishing them.He said: “They were never critical, but they would have got close to being a real challenge.“If you don’t have a proper funded plan to make sure that those stocks are maintained, they start to drop below.”Winning the funding battle with the Treasury was dficult, but Mr Wallace revealed: “Boris came to the rescue. He didn’t have to, but he did.”The £.bn cash injection only lasts until , when Mr Wallace admits the MoD will have to wage the same fight for more money again.But he says he won a key admission from No and No that the defence funding crisis must be solved for the long-term then too.Mr Wallace added: ““There is recognition by Boris Johnson, No and the Treasury now that in that we have to think that short termism has actually led to more expensive consequences.“Long-term financial planning alongside long-term ambitions is the way you get a best value for money, but also a modern st century Armed Forces that achieves the security of the country.”Shameful standards in barracks blocks will also benefit from the new money.The defence boss declared: “We have been housing our men and women in dilapidated, not fit for purpose accommodation. This new money is going to be focused often on things like that.”Mr Wallace also has bold plans to offer service families far better childcare to match the needs of a modern age.Mr Wallace is the first Defence Secretary to have been a regular serviceman since Harold Macmillan in the .During his eight years of service, he carried out several tours of Northern Ireland during the Troubles – meaning he knows what it likes to be on the receiving end of bad political leadership.He added: “The most precious equipment we have to defend our nation are the men and women.“If we don’t have the men and women with the right skills, with the right morale in our armed forces, we can’t deliver any real defence.“That’s why as long as I am Defence Secretary, I am determined to not overstretch them, not overspend and to be honest about what we can and can’t do to the rest of government.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: planning revolution building houses britain
story: The red tape will be relaxed so homes can be made bigger and new ones can be built on existing commercial sites without planning permission.House building on green belts will also be allowed where there is already some development — such as a train station.The jumbo package has been drawn up by Chancellor Sajid Javid and Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick.They will begin to unveil it at the Tories’ annual conference in Manchester, which starts tomorrow.Under the new rules, most house owners can add two more storeys to their buildings without having to make a planning application.The ministers will argue that Britain’s cities have one of the lowest average heights of housing in the Western world, and that building upwards will create a huge amount of living space immediately.The second big change means builders will no longer need permission to demolish a commercial property and replace it with homes.Many of the new policies were proposed by Mr Javid when he was Communities Secretary but blocked by the then PM Theresa May, who feared upsetting Nimbys. A senior government source said: “Sajid and Robert are taking the gloves off. We’re going to inject real dynamism into house building.“Theresa kept the handbrake on — Boris is letting them take it off.”The package is designed to deliver on the long-standing target of , new homes a year to solve the nation’s housing shortage.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: demi moore one drama to another
story: One of the many revelations was about her knickers being exposed on social media in a photo taken by her then husband Ashton Kutcher, who is said to be not best pleased about how he is portrayed in the book, Inside Out.I’m not sure Demi fully realised the impact of her “warts-and-all” memoirs, including claims that Kutcher — her much younger third husband — cheated on her and instigated “threesomes”.He’s moved on, now has a ­family with we Mila Kunis and knows that one day his two kids will read all about his behaviour during his ­marriage to Demi and find it highly embarrassing.She saw the actor,  years her ­junior, as a way to press the restart button and relive her youth all over again, but this time with a chance ofhappiness. It wasn’t to be.I first noticed Demi in , when she appeared in the movie Ghost, as fresh-faced, husky-voiced Molly, mourning the death of her husband Sam, played by Patrick Swayze.She looked adorable, with elfin cropped hair, little make-up and denim dungarees.Everyone wanted to look like this particularly gorgeous “girl next door” and that role catapulted her on to Hollywood’s A-list.Demi made a string of successful but rather questionable movies including Indecent Proposal, Striptease and GI Jane and demanded such high fees she was dubbed “Gimme Moore”, the sort of snarky comment that would never be made about a male actor.Her marriage to Bruce Willis made them the Brad and Angelina of their day, but just like that relationship, theirs too ended in tears and failure.Demi and Bruce went on to declare a truce and he was even at the launch of her new book in a show of support — although you do have to wonderhe had actually read what his ex had written about him.She claims that at the height of her fame he wanted her out of Hollywood so she could be a stay-at-home mum for their children.What strikes me about Demi’s story — from her being raped as a vulnerable  year old, to her complete ­mental breakdown after her marriage to Kutcher fell apart — was what a deeply unhappy le she has led.I honestly don’t know how any young girl would recover from being raped by a disgusting pervert who she claims “bought her” for a few hundred dollars from her alcoholic mother.How on Earth are you supposed to deal with such a horric betrayal from the one person who is supposed to love and protect you from harm It is very sad that Demi said she always felt that she was to blame for the appalling ordeal inflicted upon her by her mother and a man old enough to be her father.I think deep down she’s still that frightened, betrayed little girl who never thinks she is quite good enough.Demi writes movingly about being desperate to have a child with Kutcher.Shortly after their marriage she became pregnant, but tragically the baby died when she was six months pregnant.Again she blamed herself for the loss, and started drinking heavily.The relationship never really recovered. Years later ,just before the couple split, I interviewed Kutcher and it wasn’t a happy experience for all concerned.He wasn’t unpleasant, just deeply uncomfortable and clearly didn’t want to be promoting his latest project, but it was in his contract to so do.Everyone that day received monosyllabic replies and it was no surprise when the news broke shortly afterwards that his marriage to Demi had crumbled and that was when she started to really unravel.Even though on the outside Demi appeared to have everything — fame, enormous wealth, three healthy children and a handsome actor on her arm — inside she was a mass of ­anxiety and insecurities as she lurched from one crisis to the next.She came close to death a year after the split while partying with her oldest daughter Rumer. Demi suffered a seizure after taking drugs and inhaling nitrous oxide.That was a wake-up call for her to seek help and get her act together. Writing the book is apparently all part of the healing process.It won’t have been an easy read for her three grown-up daughters who, unsurprisingly, have apparently had their own issues with either substance abuse or insecurity about their bodies.I honestly do wonderanyone in Hollywood, especially those who find fame because of their good looks and winning smiles, are living happy, ­contented and fulfilled lives.It doesn’t look like it, and it’s deeply sad that a seemingly confident, extremely beautul woman such as Demi should have felt so worthless.All credit to her for coming back from the brink and having the guts to tell her story in her own words.But there is always collateral damage when you decide to be so honest, and I hope she is strong enough to weather the inevitable storms gathering on the horizon.Harry and Meghan brought out a secret weapon during their visit to South Africa and instantly blew away all the negativity and criticism they have experienced this year.With one cute smile and a whole lot of gurgles, baby Archie has completely rehabilitated his parents and shown them in a much happier and far more positive light.It is the first time we have properly seen the four month old and you do wonder why they haven’t shown him to the world before now.Everybody loves a baby, and Archie is a poppet, as well as being Harry’s absolute double.He has a sunny disposition and is obviously adored by his besotted mum and dad. The wee chap looked delighted to be on his first proper outing as a member of the royal firm.And Meghan is in her element. She appeared happy, relaxed and has managed to get her “look” just right.There were no designer frocks nor ostentatious jewellery. Instead it was all sustainable dresses, High Street shoes and lots of recycled outfits.Harry and Meghan have both shone a light on some hugely deserving causes and charities close to their hearts.They work well together, as well as being effective on their own, and it’s refreshing to hear them speak to the media like normal people, instead of the usual dry, formal speeches.It is in places such as Africa that they can both do such a lot of good and build on the pioneering charity work carried out by Harry’s late mum Princess Diana.Meghan telling young South African girls she is a woman of colour who feels like their sister means they can truly relate to her. The words were inspired and from the heart.There are rumours that in the future Harry, Meghan and Archie would spend half the year in southern Africa, and I reckon it’s a good idea.I’ve been lucky enough to visit this incredible part all of the world and it grabs you by the heart and doesn’t let go.Like Harry, I share a particular love of beautul Botswana, and would be delighted for themthey were lucky enough to set up a home from home there.They would be under much less pressure and scrutiny than here in the UK and able to lead almost normal lives should they so wish.Meanwhile Harry, Meghan – and especially Archie – continue with the charm offensive, breaking down barriers and becoming a force to be reckoned with.Diana would be very proud.Recycle your clothes instead of having wardrobes stuffed with cheap fashion.Stop buying plastic-wrapped fast food and maybe think about turning the bloody lights off when you leave a room.Just a thought . . .I HONESTLY think we are in imminent danger of completely losing our sense of humour and turning into a nation of po-faced bores.I couldn’t believe the reaction I got when I cheekily asked smouldering actor Jason Isaacshe was wearing shorts in an upcoming charity run for Great Ormond Street Hospital, and that I would happily run behind him for the view.It was a cheeky remark made to a delightfully naughty man, who I have interviewed many times.I knew he wouldn’t be offended in the least but would laugh heartily, which is exactly what happened. I also thought it was a fun way to promote a terric cause.I was astonished to be labelled “sexist” and “inappropriate”, which is completely OTT for such innocuous remarks.People really need to get things into perspective.Dan has brought us some of the top names in TV, movies and music, covered all the big award ceremonies and always delivers the most entertaining gossip.Here’s to the next decade of scoops, scandals and showbiz shenanigans.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boy 5 left wheelchair bound for life with cerebral palsy after chewing on a battery in mexico
story: Iker Fuentes was diagnosed with spastic quadriplegia meaning that he has dficulty controlling his limbs and is now wheelchair-bound.According to local media, the young boy from Coahuila, Mexico, was rushed to hospital by his mother Sugey after she found him chewing on a battery.Upon arrival, the boy was able to enter the hospital unaided, but his condition quickly deteriorated and doctors carried out an endoscopy, according to reports.Reports said that Iker underwent emergency surgery, but doctors could not prevent the youngster from suffering hydrocephalus, an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid within the brain.The situation has reportedly left the five-year-old confined to a wheelchair.After a month in hospital, Iker has ed home, but doctors do not believe he will ever be the same again, according to reports.Despite the negative prognosis, Ikers parents still have hope that their sons condition will improve with physical, visual and language therapies and lots of dedication.However, they are concerned they do not have enough savings to provide the boy with everything he is going to need.Battery manufacturers like Sony warn that these products often have highly toxic energy sources and can contain mercury, cadmium, lithium and lead which are extremely harmful to peoples health and the environment.

title: greta thunberg meltdown wont help world
story: However, when -year-old Greta Thunberg got on to the stage at the UN this week and had a full-on adolescent meltdown, she was deafened by the applause.Not from me she wasn’t.Because I was in the bog, being sick.“You have stolen my dreams and my childhood,” she sobbed.“We are in the beginning of a mass extinction and all you can talk about is money and fairytales of eternal economic growth. How dare you ”Right, well in the immortal words of Samuel L Jackson: “Allow me to retort.”How dare we  No. How dare you sail to America on a carbon fibre yacht that you didn’t build which cost £million, that you didn’t earn, and which has a back-up diesel engine that you didn’t mention.I’m sorry Ms Thunberg, butyou’re going to lay into my generation, you must accept it when I lay into you and yours.What about the pills you take when you have a headache What about the clean water that comes out of your tap  What about the food you can buy at any time of the day and night No -year-old was responsible for any of that.What about the aid missions currently being run in some of the poorest countries of the world, or the drugs that help keep Aids at bay Think about all the movies you’ve enjoyed. Movies made by grown-ups. And all those comedians who’ve made you laugh.And then pause for a moment to consider how soundly you sleep at night, knowing that adults are building and servicing and flying Sweden’s fighter planes. To keep you safe.We gave you mobile phones and laptops and the internet. We created the social media you use every day and we run the banks that pay for it all.So how dare you stand there and lecture us, you spoilt brat.And yes, you are spoilt because when you told your mum and dad to stop using planes and give up meat, they didn’t behave like sane parents and ignore you. They actually said, “Yes, dear.” And did.What they should have done is point out that le is tragic.Some people are born bright and some are born stupid.Some are beautul and some are not.Some have rich parents who give them everything but love.Some have poor parents who have nothing to give except love.Now shut up and let them get on with it.This is how the world works. It’s how the world has always worked.And banging your fists on the table won’t change a thing. You’ll learn that when you’ve got a few more years under your belt.I agree with you that the world is heating up. You may even be right that man has something to do with it.And there is no doubt that as deserts eat into currently habitable places in Africa and the Middle East, Europe will face an unimaginable refugee crisis.Something needs to be done about that. So how’s this for an idea. Get back to school as quickly as possible and work hard in your science lectures.Because science is what will solve the problem eventually. Not scowling and having screaming ab-dabs every five minutes.Many thousands of people who you had the temerity to blame this week are trying to do exactly what you want.So be a good girl, shut up and let them get on with it.And no. You cannot stay out past ten. And you cannot go out in a skirt that short.And the best business brains don’t come cheap.SAM Smith, who’s a singer I think, announced recently that “he” doesn’t consider “himself” to be a man or a woman and wants everyone to refer to “him” as “they” in future.They said on Instagram that they have been at war with themselves for . . . oh, I give up. It’s too dficult.It’s also dficult for the organisers of the Brit Awards, who are now having to work out whether there should be separate awards in future for men and women.Because what happensMr and or Mrs Smith wins one As non-binary people continue to increase the noise they make about their non-binariness, this is going to be a problem everywhere.It can’t be long before the right-on Oscar people have to address the issue.I bet they already have with the lavatories.And after that, there will be Wimbledon and football, where there will have to be a new league for people who aren’t men OR women.Or they will have to let women and the neither nors into the Premier League  Probably not such a bad idea at Spurs these days.Right. I see.So,the speech had been delivered by someone who began by saying: “I’m here with you as a father, a husband, a man and your brother”, would that have made what followed less important EVER since I was a small boy, people have been claiming to be on the verge of inventing a new plane which will get to Australia in time for tea.We’ve had ramjets and scramjets and rockets and all we’ve ever really seen in the flesh is Concorde, which could only carry enough fuel to reach New York, and the SR- Blackbird which could only carry one passenger.Now, though, a British company has announced the Synergetic Air Breathing Rocket Engine – Sabre – which they say will enable a passenger plane to get from London to Oz, via space, in four hours.That’s fantastic, of course, and I wish them well.But the truth is that the world doesn’t really need fast aircraft any more.The Blackbird spy plane was replaced by satellites, and Concorde was replaced by something that can get businessmen across the Atlantic in no time at all.It’s called the internet.But the trip had to be cancelled because . . . it was too windy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sajid javid home building revolution
story: Now Sajid runs the Treasury and Hammond isn’t even a Tory.Which could be great news for a young generation priced out of the housing market.A year ago The Sun attacked the Tories’ feeble efforts to build new homes. One much-trumpeted injection of funds was only enough for , a year, a fraction of the increase needed.We said only a bonfire of planning restrictions would do.And Mr Javid is promising just that, for new builds and extensions.He must also face down NIMBY neighbours and stop developers hoarding plots or releasing homes at a snail’s pace to keep prices high.We look forward to the detail . . . and hope it is not over-hyped, as so much was under Theresa May.Real change could bring homes in London and the South East within millennial buyers’ reach for the first time.Go for it, The Saj.GIVING Jeremy Corbyn power even for one ­second would harm Britain for a generation — and here’s why:To job-creating firms and foreign investors, we are a safe haven.Corbyn believes in none of that. His policies should terry anyone with a job, a business, pension, savings, a home or even a car. Labour would hammer businesses and seize private property.Remainer MPs seem tempted to install him in No “temporarily”. Remember how Labour only put the hard-left dinosaur on their leadership ballot in  to “widen the debate”  That went well.Does anyone seriously believe Marxists who have lusted after revolution for decades would surrender power once gted it  And what message will we have sent to the world eventhey did That our formerly serious country is only ever one act of madness away from installing a Marxist government with the same policies that reduced once-rich Venezuela to Third World ruin.The SNP couldn’t care less. They want to leave the UK. They will merrily help Corbyn for another independence vote.All other sane MPs must halt this lunacy.“BETRAYAL” is a word with no place in our politics, preaches holier-than-thou John Major, who used exactly that word as PM.MPs must soften their language, insists Major, who branded three Eurosceptic Tory ministers “bastards”.“Political chicanery” must not be used to take us out of the EU with No Deal, rules Major — who once swerved a scandal using his own chicanery and now backs any and all tricks to stop Brexit.Once PM. title: jeremy corbyn plans scrap universal credit
story: JEREMY Corbyn will today announce radical plans to scrap Universal Credit - but admitted he doesn’t have a plan to replace it.The Labour leader will vow to make major changes to the Government’s troubled flagship welfare programme within the first  days of his Government and ditch it totally within five years- costing taxpayers billions of pounds.The two child policy and benefit cap would be immediately ditched, he will say, and Labour will ditch sanctions for those who don’t look for work or miss crucial appointments.And he will cut the five-week wait for those going onto the new six in one benefits scheme - a key part of The Sun’s Make Universal Credit Work campaign.We have called on ministers to slash the long wait for benefits, make childcare costs available upfront, and demanded Brits get to keep more of their hard-earned cash.Mr Corbyn will say today : “When a Labour government takes office we will introduce an emergency package of reforms to end the worst aspects of Universal Credit.“And we will introduce a new system that will be based on the principles of dignity and respect and it will alleviate and end poverty, not drive people into it.”Housing benefits will be paid automatically to landlords, and Brits will be paid automatically every two weeks instead.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the Government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. He will rename the Department for Work and Pensions the Department for Social Security too.The plans will cost £billion to start with - but the future reforms could total up to far more.Despite claiming that Universal Credit is beyond repair, some policies could be kept in the new system - including the taper rate system which reduces cash as claimants work more hours.Labour refused to give any detail on when the current programme would close down completely.Thousands of Brits will be immediately stopped from being moved over onto the new system automatically.However, new claimants will apply for what the party calls a “reformed” version of the benefits system until they sort out a long-term plan.Mr Corbyn will announce the plans in a rally in the former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith’s constituency.Mr Duncan Smith, the architect of Universal Credit insisted that ditching the policy altogether would cause absolute chaos - and cause stress to millions of worried Brits.He stormed: “This is a shallow and cynical attempt to distract from all of Labour’s Brexit mess, the failure to support an election, and the cost of their open doors migration policy.“Universal Credit is working. They will trash it for the sake of a dog whistle.”New Work and Pensions boss Thérèse Coffey blasted Labour’s completely reckless ideas to rip up the current welfare policies.She said: “This is totally irresponsible from Jeremy Corbyn - who now admits he would happily scrap financial support for vulnerable people with no plan as to what Labour would replace it with.“It’s reckless, political point scoring from a Party that spent years trapping people on benefits and holding them back from the opportunities that would help them build a better future for them and their families.“It is because of policies like Universal Credit that we have supported over .m people into work since , incomes are rising at their fastest pace in over a decade and income inequality is close to a -year low.“But we know there is more to do to make the system work better for those who need it most, and this why we have recently increased the amount people can earn before their benefits are reduced by £, a year.”Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: school treorchy boy pupil poo bush
story: The boy, , was suffering from diarrhoea but the school’s policy of having a lockdown on all the toilets during classes forced the boy to find somewhere  to relieve himself.A teacher had let him out of class to go to the loo but the school receptionist refused to give him the key.He was then caught short as he ed to class and was then forced to go behind a bush near the school block.Treorchy Comprehensive in Wales said the toilets are locked during lessons but added it would examine their policy after the complaint.The youngsters mum told Wales Online: “He had diarrhoea and didn’t want it to run down his leg so he just had to find a quiet area outside.“It breaks my heart to think someone could have seen him. As far as I’m concerned it’s neglect by the school.”She added: “He wasn’t ill when he went to school but had a belly ache after lunch and said it was quite acute.“This is a health and safety issue. He could not wipe or wash his hands.“We are very happy with the school and his reports are good but I am very shocked to hear about this toilet policy.“I feel it’s very neglectful to not have free use of the toilets. They can’t just shut off the toilets like this.”The parents, who did not want to be identied to protect their son, said he told them what had happened the same evening and they went to complain to the deputy head teacher the following day.They said they were told pupils had to request a key to avoid trouble making in the toilets and kids avoiding lessons by pretending they needed to go.The parents added their son had been given permission to go to the toilet but said they didn’t know why he had been refused the key by the receptionist.They claim they were told by the deputy head he would speak to the receptionist.A spokeswoman for the ,-pupil school said: “There are nine sets of toilets located across the school site and most of these are locked during lesson times to ensure all pupils have access to the highest standards of toilet facilities when they wish to use them, upon request.“The school has procedures in place which enables pupils to use toilet facilities during lesson times. These have proven to be effective over many years.“It would not be appropriate to comment on any inidual cases but no child or young person who requires the use of a toilet is denied access.The school routinely reviews all school policies and, in light of the concern raised, an evaluation of existing procedures and policies will be undertaken.”

title: po ferry evacuated dover delays english channel
story: Hundreds of terried passengers were evacuated and two crossings were cancelled after the device was found during a routine pre-sail check.An Army bomb squad swarmed the :am service within hours of the discovery.A PO Ferries spokesman said: A suspicious package was found on one of our ships this morning.The authorities are currently in attendance, and all passengers and non-essential crew have been evacuated as a precaution.A Dover port spokesman added: The Port of Dover can confirm there was a security alert this morning on board a PO ferry within the Port which temporarily affected journey times and some ferry departures while the authorities were in attendance.A number of passengers were transferred to the Port’s Passenger Services West building prior to disembarking their vehicles.The incident has now been stood down and the port is fully operational with ferry sailings continuing as normal.Ferry passenger Susanne Trokhymenko said: We were told by staff that it was a major bomb scare! Police, ambulances and lots of staff all over the docking areaTraffic-calming measures have been put in place to deal with a backlog of lorries on the A.Delays are expected this morning on all routes out of Dover.

title: prince harry angola south africa meghan
story: Soldiers in unorm saluted the Duke of Sussex as he arrived on a red carpet to hold talks with Joao Lourenco at the presidential palace in Luanda. The meeting comes after a packed Friday, in which he visited a landmine clearance project that featured in some of the most famous photographs of his late mother, Princess Diana.The Duke, , has briefly parted ways with Meghan, , and their four-month-old son after they all landed in South Africa on Monday.Their first overseas tour as a family has featured engagements including visits to poor townships and a meeting with Nobel Peace Prize laureate Desmond Tutu.Theyll reunite towards the end of the ten-day trip in Johannesburg on Wednesday, before ing to the UK.Before that, Harry will today visit a hospital to see the work of a project spearheaded by Angolas first lady, Ana Dias Lourenco.The project focuses on preventing the transmission of HIV AIDS from mothers to their babies in a country where high fertility, a young population and lack of awareness are driving infection rates up.On Sunday the prince will move on to Malawi, again for his first official visit, though he has visited the country several times privately in the past.

title: uber eats delivery caught camera poo
story: The East European man with an upset stomach handed Curtis McGreevy a Chicken Legend meal, chicken nuggets and cheese dippers before defecating outside a neighbours house.Unknown to the desperate Uber Eats driver, who is called Ivaylo, his unordered delivery was recorded on Harry Merchants CCTV.It was yesterday still in place to the left of the front door of Harrys home in Corby, Northants.He and Curtis have been told by Environmental Health that specialists will clear it up because of the danger of hepatitis.Curtis, , said: I came home from a  to  hours sht on Sunday and thought I am not cooking Sunday dinner.It was five or six oclock. The kids wanted a takeaway so I used the Uber Eats App.It came to around £. plus the £. for the Uber driver.His details came up on the order and he came round with the order and I didnt think any more of it until Harry told me what he had done.Curtis, who works as a supermarket manager, lives with his we Frankie, , and two children.He went on: What happened next was disgusting. Kids play out there.The driver clearly had an upset stomach and should have called in sick.I dont think for a moment that it was the first time he had pooed on that sht.He had toilet roll with him, he came prepared.The app asks rate the order. I gave it a big fat zero. I wont be using it.Sun Online has contacted Uber for a comment and is awaiting a reply.

title: groom thomas cook saved dream wedding thomas cook bust
story: Thomas,  and his we, Amelia Cook, , had their romantic Greek island wedding saved at the last minute when the Lindos Princess Hotel stepped in to help re-organise their big day.The four star hotel on the island of Rhodes were on hand to provide flowers and champagne and help with the marriage license paperwork at the town hall after their dream wedding was cancelled at the last minute.The couple had to cover most of the costs themselves, but say they got help from a local wedding company and incredible staff at the resort who worked for free to help them put their big day together.Family and friends also helped with costs by setting up GoFundMe pages.Thomas and Amelia said they were delighted with the ceremony - the only downside being that a few of their wedding party were unable to make it due to the Thomas Cook travel chaos.The happy couple said: We were extremely relieved.We were happy that most people were there but we were still missing a few people.Wed like to thank Princess Lindos beach resort, especially Dora. Hatty, the Thomas cook wedding co-ordinatar, for working for free.Lindos Wedding Karen Harvey, for offering for services for free make up and photography by Antonis Giannelis.And Charlotte Samantha for the GoFundMe page.We are looking forward to our wedding reception when wehome and seeing all of our family and friends.The pair, from Hucknall, Notts, flew out last week and were due to marry at the hotel on the Greek island of Rhodes, but their plans were thrown into chaos when Thomas Cook announced it would cease trading.The couple had paid out £, with the now bust travel firm to plan their big day and fly out family and friends.The Thomas Cook package the couple had paid for was set to include the wedding ceremony, flowers, cake, decorations and entertainment.But the devastated couple were left stranded on the Greek Island and told the ceremony may not go ahead.Thomas, who works for Rolls-Royce, told Nottinghamshire Live on Monday: Thomas Cook promised us a surprise on our wedding because of my name but this was not the surprise we were expecting.I am just devastated. We have got more than  friends and family coming out, half are stuck at home in limbo. My best man is still in England. No one here knows anything.I have been planning this for two years and it has all gone to pot. We have paid for everything. It is shattering.We dont know what we can do. Thomas Cook staff have been good but they lost their jobs.The couple, who have been together for  years, decided to marry abroad because it was cheaper to marry in Rhodes than having a wedding in the UK.However, when the hotel heard the news, they stepped in to save the couples dream wedding, pulling out all the stops to ensure Thomas and Amelia had their special day after two years of planning.Giorgos Bakas, manager at the Lindos Princess hotel told Sun Online:He just looked so disappointed and we didn’t want him to leave like that.We are honoured that he has come to our hotel, our island and Greece. Many guests were already in Rhodes when the news broke, with only the best man having to book an alternative flight, with the whole wedding party will be flown home on repatriation flights after the big day.Thomas Cook went bust in the early hours of Monday morning after failing to secure a last-ditch rescue deal, with all future flights and holidays cancelled.As many as , Thomas Cook employees among , staff around the world have also lost their jobs - many who have bravely ploughed on today to help the holidaymakers affected.

title: beyonce jay z fame blue ivy
story: Perhaps the main one is that she’s had her own personal stylist and shopper since she could toddle her way on to the red carpet, and she is only seven years old.At one Grammy Awards, for example, she wore a white Valery Kovalska tuxedo pantsuit with sparkling silver shoes and a beaded black clutch.That was the time — remember  — when at the age of six she shushed her parents from clapping too loudly when Camila Cabello introduced U to the stage.A couple of years ago she was actually named “best dressed” at the Grammy’s thanks to her pink Gucci power suit.Sitting on the front row watching her mother perform, she had the poise of someone five times her age.While other celebrities tend to shield their children from the public eye, Jay Z and Beyonce seem to have positively ushered their daughter towards it.They have been bringing her with them on tour and to ious award shows and events at which, thanks to her stylist, she often looks more fashionable than her parents.So there’s that.Butit’s hard to fathom a child in a Gucci suit, try getting your head around this: At the age of seven, when most children are still harbouring fantasies of being an astronaut, or a unicorn, little Blue Ivy, it turns out, wants to be recognised as a “cultural icon”.Well, I say Blue Ivy, but clearly it is her parents who are pushing this agenda.Beyonce and Jay Z have been seeking to trademark either “Blue Ivy” or “Blue Ivy Carter” for several years.The problem is that someone  has already trademarked the name. Beyonce has been involved in a trade-mark dispute for years against Wendy Morales, whose wedding planning business goes by the same name.Beyonce is outraged at the idea that Blue Ivy Carter, “the daughter of two of the most famous performers in the world”, might be confused with a boutique wedding event planning business.Which is unlikely, when you really think about it.So you might wonder why — really — Beyonce gives a flying fig about the fact that it has the same name as her daughter.But I guess — unless you are the mother of a cultural icon — it’s hard for mere mortals like us to understand.Beyonce has accused Morales of riding her coattails. Who knows, maybe she is. But so what What seems more relevant is the degree to which these parents apparently view their daughter as an extension of themselves.They care more about their fame and reputation than they do about letting Blue Ivy forge her own path, find her own identity and be herself.Yes, we all pass on our values and, to a degree, our aspirations to our children.But we all owe it to our kids to be aware of where we stop and they begin.And it seems to me that Beyonce and Jay Z are robbing their daughter of her childhood and suffocating her with their own aspirations.We only have to take one look around at those who haven’t been allowed proper childhoods — Michael Jackson, Macaulay Culkin, Aaron Carter — to see how badly things can go wrong.Forget designer clothes and cultural icon status, the best thing Blue Ivy’s parents could give her is a proper childhood.We all think our kids are special. Most of us do our best NOT to spoil our kids and keep them grounded, they seem to want the opposite.They need to teach her that money and status is not as important as family, values, morals, kindness — and friends. THIS week I am mainly feeling fed up with politicians.I voted Remain because the chaos of leaving far outweighed any problems of staying in.But the country voted Leave and I accepted that. What’s the point in asking the country to votethe result is ignored Three years on and we are still waiting to leave. Boris Johnson is at least trying to honour the people’s decision.Jo Swinson for the Lib Debs, who is held up as a shining new light in politics, has said thather party wins an election – most unlikely – she will cancel Brexit on the basis that on the first vote the margin for Leave was so small and people didn’t know what they were voting for.But those are just excuses. She, and others, think they know best and would no doubt keep having the vote until they get the result they want – to remain in Europe.Politicians are trying to force a Remain outcome, through delays to Brexit, not calling a general election and following their own views on the EU rather than that of the country.But crashing out without a deal is not what really worries me. It’s the prospect of a Jeremy Corbyn government.Here is a man who sympathises with Russia – although they came here and killed people, including poisoning a police officer.A man who sympathises with the IRA, met with Hamas and Hezbollah and refused to sing the National Anthem.A man who wants to close private schools and implement a four-day week .This is a man who wants to introduce a right-to-buy scheme for private tenants and force landlords to sell their buy-to-rent properties for less than they are worth, leaving them in debt – then also clobber them with higher taxes.He wants to nationalise industry and confiscate £billion of shares in , large companies and hand them to workers.As Margaret Thatcher said, the problem with socialism is you eventually run out of other people’s money.I hope politicians knock their heads together, compromise, get out of Europe and focus on the future outside of the EU – new trade deals, new investments, jobs and innovation.This is a great country, let’s hope it remains so.I KNOW Phoebe Waller- Bridge is not for everyone – although her telly show Fleabag is pretty damned funny.But whether you like her or not, she is currently on a title: political judges scrutiny remainers bidding
story: “Boris is unfit to be PM!” “Boris must resign!” “Boris lied to the Queen!”Will these idiots bring a vote of no confidence in such a terrible man  Er, no. They’re STILL terried it would ­trigger an election he would win. So they STILL won’t test their convictions at the ballot box  Er, no.“Bring it on!” they bellow. But not yet.They think voters are mugs, don’t they They have opposed any form of Brexit. They have voted to keep our Brexit-backing Government paralysed but in office. They are racing to thwart the ­referendum at all costs.And now the Supreme Court has done their bidding.Boris, victim of yesterday’s staggering legal coup, has to respect this court and its ­supposed impartiality. But in one unprecedented act of constitutional vandalism  judges became an unelected political entity, granting themselves immense power to ­overrule our Government and Queen.The PM suspended Parliament on his Attorney General’s advice. In the High Court, the Lord Chief Justice, the Master of the Rolls and President of the Queen’s Bench ision agreed with him, correctly concluding that judges should not overrule political decisions.The Supreme Court outlawed it anyway.They humiliated Boris, without whom Remainers know Brexit won’t happen. They handed victory to an anti-democratic political movement hell-bent on stopping the .million majority getting what MPs promised.They effectively granted the power to rule not to our actual Government but to a rogue Speaker and an unelected Remainer pseudo-government too cowardly to seek a mandate. It is staggeringly incendiary.Andthese judges are to be politically active, they must prepare for the scrutiny and even the elections that go with it.For three years smug, elite Remainers lied about respecting the Brexit result. They have decided they, not the people, know what’s best for us and that their lavishly-funded campaigns and QCs will see to it via our courts.They still lack the guts to ask the electorate. But yesterday’s verdict may yet give them the courage to go for broke over Brexit.The Lib Dems simply want to cancel it. Others will back a second referendum which ­Labour’s Brexit spokesman has effectively admitted would be blatantly rigged.The question would pit Remain against a supersoft “Leave” option worse than Remaining. Sixteen-year-olds would vote, maybe even EU citizens.It would be illegitimate. ButRemain won, that would be that. Forever.The EU is an undemocratic, festering sore which is crumbling economically. But ­membership is now a religion which Remain diehards cannot renounce.They are willing to trash our democracy to get their way, while complacently trusting that Britain is too peaceable to do anything but roll over. The Supreme Court seems to have made the same calculation.It is monstrously reckless. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dr rosena allin khan pm
story: NewsopinionDr Rosena Allin-Khan: PM must be a healer and act like a statesmanSince the Brexit vote, I have experienced the politics of hate and nothing  — so Boris Johnsons callous attitude is not welcomeShareCommentsByDr Rosena Allin-Khan:,  SEP NewsopinionBoris Johnson needs to come to terms with the fact that hatred is strangling our country "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI was elected on the day Jo Cox was taken from us. The EU referendum was a week later, and all I have ­experienced since then is a politics of hate. We want discourse not ision, we come to Parliament with reason not rage, and we aim to speak with humility not “humbug”. Whichever side of the Brexit fence you sit on, you’ll agree that our country is damaged with ision, and it’s being fuelled by anger. Tensions can run high, families have Brexit disagreements, so do neighbours, and Twitter and Facebook can unearth the strongest of opinions. So Parliament must take a lead and show it can have a respectful debate. To say I was disappointed with the language used by Boris Johnson this week would be an understatement.  I would plead with him to reduce the aggression and stop the finger-pointing. As the person who holds the highest position in the UK, Boris Johnson must show leadership. Sometimes this means holding your hands up and admitting that you made a mistake. Boris Johnson must apologise. While all MPs and elected representatives have a ­responsibility to lead by example, the rise of the far-right in the UK is ­responsible for attacks on minorities. Jo Cox was killed by a far-right extremist. Women MPs are issued rape threats, MPs of colour are told to “go back home”. These threats are not isolated. They sit within a ­society which is becoming increasingly aggressive towards minorities. This is the work of the far-right. Remember, just this month the police said that the fastest-growing UK terrorist threat is from the ­far-right.

story: NewsBrit trophy hunters slay at risk zebras and post sick snaps on FacebookEXCLUSIVE: They target species with dwindling population on their twisted ego trips which see them pose with dead beasts after paying to kill via hunting websitesShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  SEP NewsHunting tour operator Andy Denson and a zebra that has just been gunned down"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPosing up for sickening photos, here are the Brits who slay ­zebras for cheap thrills on South African safari holidays. One of the tour operators, Andy Denson, posted his vile snap as a souvenir of a hunt on his Facebook page. Thrill-seeker Pete Livesey smiles beside his bleeding “trophy” in another picture that will horry animal lovers. On the website of the popular Huntershill Safaris, Livesey says of his experience of killing an animal: “Never had so much fun with my pants on.”    Six other British tourists, including a woman, also grin after gunning down zebras for trophies on the website of ­another company called Umlilo Safaris. The zebra is classied as vulnerable on the International Union of the Conservation of Nature’s red list of threatened species. Yet the creatures are one of the most popular trophies for UK hunters – with hundreds of body parts hauled back here in recent years.    They are hunted on the South African plains, where it is not illegal. In the UK a ban on the import of sick souvenirs from trophy-hunters such as Denson and Livesey is now being urgently considered by government ministers. Zac Goldsmith, animal welfare ­minister, told the Sunday People this week: “I look at the photos and it turns my stomach.”    Mr Goldsmith pledged a consultation on stopping the imports of trophy hunt parts with view to stopping this vile trade. Hunter Denson is one of the country’s top taxidermists – turning murdered ­animals into ghoulish figures to be hung on walls. He is also cashing in by helping to set up trips to slaughter big game, claiming it is for conservation. The -year-old from Padiham, Lancs, is listed as the UK agent for Thaba Thala Safaris – ­popular with ­hunters from the UK.    Wealthy Brits have bragged about their ­cruel ­exploits during the trips, which start at £, for seven days. Hunters can add animals to kill from a list of  species, including £ to add a zebra and £ ­taxidermy fees. But Eduardo Goncalves of the Campaign to Ban Trophy Hunting branded the safaris as evil. He said: “So many of Africa’s greatest wild animals are ­already suffering thanks to the vile trophy ­hunting industry. “Now ­zebras have joined the list. In April last year zebras were ­officially listed as vulnerable. The Grévy’s zebra species is listed as ­endangered.“What is it going to take to stop these killers from wiping out our wildle completely   “Unbelievably, there are ­hardly any legal ­restrictions on shooting zebras for fun.”Denson, who has been a taxidermist for  years, boasts how he has slaughtered “every species in the eastern Cape” of South Africa and how he “love hunting but love hunting ­alongside my son even more”. On his website he adds: “I was born and bred in the countryside and feel ­I ­understand country le and the wildle that lives within it. “For the past  years I’ve provided a full taxidermy ­service mounting birds, ­mammals and specialising in deer, African and exotic shoulder and pedestal mounts from my ­studio in Padiham, Lancashire. “In the early s my family relocated to the eastern cape of South Africa where they have lived ever since. “My auntie was a manager on one of the biggest privately owned game reserves in South Africa and for the past  years I have spent most of my time studying and hunting there. “I have been glad to see my son follow in my footsteps to become a very well ­respected professional hunter and fisherman taking clients out to fulfil their African dreams.”Mr Goncalves said: “No wonder our wildle is in the terrible situation that it’s in. There needs to be an ­immediate moratorium on the sport-hunting of all threatened animals. “The Government should ban imports of ­hunting trophies and call on other countries to join it. It’s the only way to end this evil trade.” Latest estimates put the ­remaining population of zebras at , – less than one-tenth the number of African ­elephants. And the zebra’s popularity among British trophy hunters is making the picture worse, ­according to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. Between - UK hunters brought in  zebra trophies.In the following decade, -, the number jumped to  zebra trophies, up  per cent.    Zebra are legal to hunt in South Africa and hunt organisers charge cheaper fees for them.By ­contrast it costs tens of thousands of pounds to hunt lions and elephants.Another firm attracting Brits is Huntershill in South Africa.Pete Livesey is pictured on the Huntershill site next to a slaughtered zebra with his boast about how much fun he is having with his pants on.

Disabled children and former Grenfell residents living at The Westbourne Place in Maida Vale, which is owned by housing association Octavia, were barred from entering the communal gardens. Residents of the private properties in Westbourne Place, where homes have been sold for £,, were given fobs to enable access to the communal garden. But social housing residents were denied the privilege and instead locked out of these spaces. Octavia blocked access to these spaces to avoid tenants facing the financial burden of high service charges, which were originally set by developer Redrow but are now managed by Pinnacle Property Management which runs the private side of the development. Redrow’s original plans for the luxury flats showed the gardens to be accessible for all those who lived there. These plans were approved by Westminster Council, but are now the subject of an enforcement investigation by council officers. The affordable and social housing tenants pay more than £ a month in service charges per home.    Speaking to , one family with a disabled child said they had been fighting for much-needed parking access from Pinnacle Property Management for several months. In March, London Mayor Sadiq Khan and former housing minister James Brokenshire spoke on the topic of segregating communal gardens, promising to change the law to ban the shameful practice. However, it seems that social housing residents are still facing discrimination. A former Grenfell Tower resident who lost his -year-old father in the Grenfell Tower fire, said his flat overlooks the garden and he is desperate to move before his son gets older. Hamid Al Jafari told : He asks all the timehe can play football in the garden. “Luckily he is only five so I can try to distract him and say we should play somewhere . I am already suffering with depression from what I went through at Grenfell. Another resident, Ahmed Ali, revealed his son, , was unable to play with his best friend who lives on the private side adding that it is open discrimination.

story: NewsMums entire memory wiped clean after she collapses and dies for  minutesTracey Deimert, , from Bridgwater in Somerset, can no longer remember her childhood, wedding or birth of her sons after her heart stopped for reasons doctors cannot explainShareCommentsByRichard MillsAmber Hicks:,  SEP Updated:,  SEP NewsDoctors feared Tracey would remain in a persistent vegetative state - but she stunned with her recovery "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Tracey Deimert canapost remember her wedding, birth of her children or anything  that happened in the first  years of her le. She only has pictures to reflect on treasured moments and relatives who have since died, but she cannot recall ever meeting, reports Somerset Live. The -year-old was visiting parents Sue and Trevor in Bridgwater, when suddenly, her heart stopped inexplicably and she collapsed in the kitchen. The then -year-old, also from Bridgwater, was without a pulse for  agonising minutes, causing a hypoxic brain injury.  Her husband Garry was warned by doctors that her brain had been starved of oxygen for so long that it was very likely she would remain in a persistent aposvegetative stateapos. But Tracey, a former dispensing optometrist, had other ideas. Iaposm a fighter. Even when things are down, you should never give up, she said. Against all the odds, Traceyaposs eyes flickered open in what was a aposmiraculousapos turn of events. But everything she had experienced in her -years her childhood, her marriage, the birth of her sons Cameron and Bradley - she remembers none of it. When she awoke in hospital, Garry and her two kids were looking on at her but she showed not the faintest recognition of who they were.    Garry said: She didnapost know I was her husband and that she had two children. All her memories had gone forever. It was heartbreaking for us. It took months for her to learn how to speak again and when she did, those memories remained lost. She had no idea who we were. She asked me, aposWho are those people  and I said, aposThey are your sonsapos, said Garry. Then she said, aposWho is that person in the picture apos, and I said, aposThat is you on your wedding day.apos With a smile she said, aposI look pretty.apos It was heartbreaking for us. For her to ask this was so hard to take. She loved us all very much and then she didnapost know who we were. It was unbelievably dficult to take.   months on from her fall, Tracey was taken back to her home and set about trying to continue her le again. But it wasnapost easy. She had to learn how to speak, eat, talk and walk again. I had forgotten who I was, said Tracey. It was the worst thing, a complete memory loss. I wish I could remember more. There was nothing wrong with my heart. The doctors couldnapost find out why it just stopped. They said I was going to be in a vegetative state. They said I was non-responsive. But I am a big fighter. For some reason, I can remember music and how to dance. Pictures sometimes help, but most of it has gone.  My motor skills are not very good. One day I went for a walk and got lost. I was very scared. But a friend found me and brought me home. I didnapost remember my home when I first came back from hospital. Tracey cannot recall when she met Garry as a teenager at school. She also cannot remember when they dated there for a while, when they broke up and when they got back together again, after both had marriages of their own, in . Garry says, however, that he is trying to give her great, new memories for her to treasure, but le is still not easy. She never lost her memory of music. She can sing along to loads of songs and remember the words, said Garry, a maintenance technician at Hinkley Point power station.  She can read but she cannot really make sense of it. Her memory is still affected. She struggles to do everyday things. But her recovery was miraculous. The original prognosis was that she was not going to recover at all. There was no response for four weeks. Her recovery should be celebrated. She is a medical marvel. He added: It was just horrendous. She was, and still is, the nicest person in the world. Sheaposs the most beautul, loving and amazing person I have ever met. Sometimes she does get very frustrated. She used to drive, work and do lots of things. Now, she canapost do a lot of those things. But she has made real progress. Exactly  years on from the ordeal, she has made big strides with the help of her family, friends and Brunelcare.

title: mum who thought would never

Hollie Tomlinson, , had always dreamed of having children after coming from a large family where she was one of six siblings. However, her chances were reduced when she was diagnosed with polycystic oy syndrome , which reduces fertility in women. It is thought that one in every five women in the UK suffers from the condition. After trying for over three years with her husband Christian, the child practitioner thought she would never conceive, but Hollie was referred to an IVF clinic nevertheless. After just one round of treatment on the NHS, Hollie went for a pregnancy test in hospital and discovered that she was pregnant. Tiny Ellia Tomlinson became the youngest member of the five-generation family when she was born on July , weighing lb oz.    Hollie, of Grimsby, said: She is certainly a miracle, I didnapost think Iaposd ever have a child. We had been trying for three and half years, we started trying to before we got married. After a year of trying and not being pregnant, I thought something was wrong so I went to see a doctor. Hollie was diagnosed with PCOS, which causes the oies to enlarge and surrounds eggs with fluid filled sacs, which reduce fertility.  It is thought that while one in five UK women live with PCOS, half of them do not display any symptoms. Although there is currently no cure for PCOS, Manchester-based healthy-eating coach Norah Cozens claims this bizarre diet can tackle the condition.  After starting IVF , Hollie was dealt a further blow when doctors told her that her eggs were not growing inside the incubator. Things changed just days later when doctors contacted her again. I got a bit upset when they said they hadnapost grown, but two days later they rang me up and said aposyour eggs have grown and we can take themapos. Ellia Tomlinson was welcomed in the world by her family including mum Hollie, granddad Richard Stocks, , great-grandmother Susan Stocks, , and great-great-grandmother Eileen Petchey, .  Besotted Hollie said: Sheaposs doing well, sheaposs putting weight on, sheaposs up to lb oz and is keeping me up at night Itaposs surreal, I have been with my partner for seven years and we had our house how we like it. Now, every room has a bit of her in it. Elliaaposs birth now means that five generations of the family are all living at the same time. Hollie was particularly chuffed that her great-great-grandmother could meet Ellia. She said: My great-grandma is so pleased she got to meet her. Being  is a great age, Iaposm really happy that sheaposs still here to see me have my own child. Sheaposs seen me grow up and now she has seen me have a child of my own. Sheaposs smitten with Ellie and she sees a lot of her.  Hollie revealed the miracle news to her family with a Christmas card addressed to Nana and granddad. She said: I put a picture of the embryo and the test in the card and wrote aposIaposll see you in nine months. But she didnapost let us wait nine months, she came six weeks early. story: NewsSingle mum on Universal Credit says she can only afford £ pizza due to nursery costsA single mother who switched to Universal Credit in June has said she fears she will have to quit her job as exorbitant nursery costs leave her only being able to afford £ pizzas to feed herselfShareCommentsByZoe ChamberlainKaisha Langton:,  SEP Updated:,  SEP NewsKimberley Hill said all she can afford is leftovers from her childrens meals made up of £ chips and pizzas "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA single working mum has said she is struggling to feed herself since switching to Universal Credit because of sky-high nursery fees. Kimberley Hill, from Birmingham, said she fears she will be forced to give up her job because nursery costs are leaving her with no funds to feed herself, Birmingham Live reports . The -year-old mother of two switched to Universal Credit at the end of June, believing it would be better for her family. The mum from Telford took an advance payment loan of £, to cover her between the period when her benefits stopped and her Universal Credit started. Ms Hill was surprised to learn she was required to get a job, after her youngest son Austin turned three in August, as the looking for work age had reduced from having a child aged five to three.  But undeterred, the single mum started a part time job in logistics admin by September . As a working mother, she should now be entitled to  hours free childcare per week, but she missed the deadline to apply , as she had not been intending toto work before then. Ms Hill now faces monthly outgoings of £ for nursery fees and £ for after-school care for her five-year-old Wyatt, which is more than the £ she is paid each month. Currently, Ms Hill receives £, Universal Credit per month, but this will be reduced signicantly when she starts receiving her monthly salary. She says that, after a £ allowance, her payment will reduce by p for every pound she earns. In total, Ms Hillaposs monthly outgoings come to £,..    Ms Hill said: I’m so saddened they expect me toto work and are so eager for me to do so and, when I have found something, I have no support whatsoever,” said Kimberley, from Telford. “My salary doesn’t even cover my childcare costs let alone any other bills. I cannot afford to pay for my childcare upfront.Working parent recipients of Universal Credit are entitled to claim up to % of their childcare costs, but the bills must be paid upfront by the parents and then reclaimed. But Kimberley says she is unable to do this as her rent needs to be paid upfront and her salary and Universal Credit are both paid in arrears. The cash-strapped mum has been in and out of hospital for digestive problems that doctors have diagnosed as a result of her poor diet and the lack of healthy food she eats. She said: I feed the kids then I have whatever’s left over. Healthy food is expensive, cheap food isn’t so much. The doctors say I’m not getting enough fruit and veg but I cannot comprehend spending much money on a meal. All I can afford is £ pizza and £ chips.    But the mother had truly thought Universal Credit was the best option for her family. She said: I switched to Universal Credit because I was struggling to save my weekly income support benefits to pay my monthly bills,”  said Kimberley, who says her mum and dad help her out when they can but that she doesnapost like to ask them. “I felt this decision would be best for me and my boys as Universal Credit is paid monthly. The first payment takes four to five weeks to come through but your benefits stop straight away.  I had to try to find money for new unorm and shoes. I cannot get a credit card, overdraft or loans because of a debt relief order. I’ve had to call on a neighbour to borrow some money to pay my car insurance. Sometimes I wish I hadn’t come off income support because at least I had my bills paid. But it was hardI needed a new tyre on my car or my son got a hole in his school jumper. Itaposs confusing because the amount of Universal Credit I get changes every month depending on how much childcare Iaposm claiming and how much money Iaposm earning. But it feels like I get a lot less money now. Her working schedule means that the working mum is required to pay for a full dayaposs nursery fee even though she only works between pm and pm. Until her claim to  hours a week of free childcare is increased in January, Ms Hill is only able to claim  hours per week now. The mother of two said: No wonder some people choose to just pop another child out, probably an easier option because it’s so much stress, but thataposs having a child for the wrong reasons. I didn’t expect to be a single mum. I had been with my partner for years but it didn’t work out.    Work coaches at Jobcentres are able to offer eligible claimants a Flexible Support Fund, which is a non-repayable award to help with upfront childcare costs in order to start work. Ms Hill applied for this but was told she would likely be denied as the amount she needed was so high. She said: I’m not looking for money I can blow on me, I’m just trying to do better for me and my kids. I don’t even knowI can cope with the stress or worry. I’m just taking it a day at a time and praying I get accepted for the Flexible Support Fund to tide me over. If I don’t then Iaposll have to quit my job and they will chase me to search for a new one. It will be a never ending circle. The Department for Work and Pensions team has said their team is looking into Ms Hillaposs case and have agreed to offer her help from the Flexible Support Fund. A Government spokesperson said:  We’re committed to helping everyone access the support they need. Up-front care costs can be claimed out of the Flexible Support Fund and Ms Hill’s claim has been allowed. With Universal Credit, working parents can recover up to  per cent of eligible childcare costs. Ms Hill has also applied for up to  hours free childcare to begin in January, and advice for families about when to claim is available online.
